results.title: How long is a piece of string (preview for an interactive work)
results.creator_credit: Advanced Diploma of Multimedia (ADoM), Swinburne University of Technology (formerly Electronic Design and Interactive Media (EDIM) and Judith Graham
results.brief_description: as part of the end of year screening for the Swinburne, EDIM (Electronic Design and Interactive Media) course - those students who had completed interactive coursework were required to create a linear representation of their work for the showreel. This student should be contacted and asked to submit the full work to the Interactive collection

results.title: How long is a minute?
results.brief_description: Divides the screen into five separate images to show visually a precise minute, without any reference to clocks or seconds. Reveals what can be done in less time and what takes longer.

results.title: How lightning shatters wood : the primeaval steam engine
results.brief_description: SUMMARY:Illustrates some of the effects of lightning. Shows alaboratory demonstration of lightning shattering wood. Lightning shatters trees with steam, this steam energy being converted into kinetic energy

results.title: How life begins
results.creator_credit: Gene Feldman, Daniel Wilson, American Broadcasting Company and Jules Power Productions
results.brief_description: Provides an understanding of the many and varied ways in which organisms, both simple and complex, reproduce. Introduces concepts of mitosis, courtship, nesting, fertilization and embryological development. Narrated by Eddie Albert.

results.title: How level is sea level
results.creator_credit: Larry Klingman and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Defines mean sea level and explains how it is determined. Describes factors that influence sea level at various locations, and analyses the problems of creating a sea level canal in Central America.

results.title: How language grows
results.creator_credit: John Honey, Barry Pierce and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Examines the various stages of language development in children from birth to six-year-old. Shows how parents can positively support and contribute to their child’s language development.

results.title: How Jane Conquest Rang the Bell
results.brief_description: Jane’s conquest was a melodramatic magic lantern show which was hugely popular and performed with reading of poem by Dr Croft who rewrote and adapted the poem by James Milne. It featured an early form of special effects, by use of a second magic lantern slide projected over the first with a biunial magic lantern. This is considered to be an early form of superimpostion, which became a common effect in photography and cinematography. It consisted of 17 slides to be used on a biunial magic lantern, the 17th slide being of an angel to be superimposed over slide 4 and 16 to suggest the presence of an angel.
results.description: Jane’s conquest was a melodramatic magic lantern show which was hugely popular and performed with reading of poem by Dr Croft who rewrote and adapted the poem by James Milne. results.title: How its surface changes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Understanding Our Earth”.
Explains the slow but constant changes in the surface of the earth by showing the erosive effects of water and wind upon a recently excavated mound of raw earth. Includes scenes of the eruption of the Paracutin Volcano, the Grand Canyon of the Colorado River, and a rocky mountainside, pointing out the geologic evidence of forces which continue to build up and wear away the surface of the earth.

results.title: How it works
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Open hearth furnace series”.
An explanation of how the furnace is constructed to withstand the very high temperatures needed to make steel. The system of regeneration by which gas and air are heated before being burned in the furnace is also illustrated.

results.title: How it happens
results.creator_credit: Victorian Road Safety Division and Ritter-Jepperson Studios
results.brief_description: The experiences of a small boy, injured in a road accident, are used to emphasise why children should obey the following safety rules: play where it is safe - not on the roadways; look both ways when crossing streets; never ride bicycles more than two abreast; never run out onto roads from behind stationary vehicles.
